channel.title: Graphics Card help
channel.description: I finally got my Nvidia GeForce GTX 660ti graphics card, but it seems like a few games aren't using the dedicated graphics card, but instead using my integrated graphics. I was wondering if there is anyway I can fix this?

item.title: Graphics Card help
item.dc:creator: @Tutorial Tutorial
item.description:
@Tutorial wrote:

SilentCJ:

My GTX 680 stays at a solid 50 (seems vsync prevents it from going any higher) at the grand exchange, but I’d say that’s pretty normal. My old laptop with slightly less powerful graphics used to do the same thing.

I’ve even tried disabling Vsync, because that limits the FPS output of your graphics card. Anyways, I think the maximum FPS you can hold on RuneScape is 50.

Read full topic

item.title: Graphics Card help
item.dc:creator: @SilentCJ SilentCJ
item.description:
@SilentCJ wrote:

My GTX 680 stays at a solid 50 (seems vsync prevents it from going any higher) at the grand exchange, but I’d say that’s pretty normal. My old laptop with slightly less powerful graphics used to do the same thing.

item.title: Graphics Card help
item.dc:creator: @Tutorial Tutorial
item.description:
@Tutorial wrote:

Travas:

I would go ahead and say it isn’t normal. I have a low end card that’s around ~$80 that runs RuneScape beautifully with no lag whatsoever, so you should be running RuneScape with your high-end card flawlessly. Is RuneScape the only game that is giving you problems?

Pretty much.

HcoJustin:

Run the “renderer” command in the dev console and give us the output. Make sure you are in OpenGL or DirectX mode too and not software mode


Running max settings at Slayer tower and I’m barely holding 30 FPS.

Read full topic

item.title: Graphics Card help
item.dc:creator: @HcoJustin HcoJustin
item.description:
@HcoJustin wrote:

[quote=“Tutorial, post:14, topic:508488”][quote author=Travas link=topic=626727.msg4263020#msg4263020 date=1363636756]
70c is a tad bit higher than usual, I wouldn’t really worry about it though. My card runs at about 24c idling, and doesn’t go much higher while gaming.

Are you still having problems running games through your graphics card? What specific games allow you to use the dedicated graphics card, and what ones make you use the integrated graphics?
[/quote]
Turns out that my integrated graphics are disabled, so my dedicated graphics card has been working. I was holding lower FPS while in populated areas. For example: I was at the Grand Exchange and was experiencing a lot of FPS drops and low FPS in general. Is this normal?[/quote]
Run the “renderer” command in the dev console and give us the output. Make sure you are in OpenGL or DirectX mode too and not software mode

Read full topic

item.dc:creator: @Travas Travas

@Travas wrote:

I would go ahead and say it isn’t normal. I have a low end card that’s around ~$80 that runs RuneScape beautifully with no lag whatsoever, so you should be running RuneScape with your high-end card flawlessly. Is RuneScape the only game that is giving you problems?

item.title: Graphics Card help
item.dc:creator: @Tutorial Tutorial
item.description:
@Tutorial wrote:

[quote=“Travas, post:13, topic:508488”]70c is a tad bit higher than usual, I wouldn’t really worry about it though. My card runs at about 24c idling, and doesn’t go much higher while gaming.

Are you still having problems running games through your graphics card? What specific games allow you to use the dedicated graphics card, and what ones make you use the integrated graphics?[/quote]
Turns out that my integrated graphics are disabled, so my dedicated graphics card has been working. I was holding lower FPS while in populated areas. For example: I was at the Grand Exchange and was experiencing a lot of FPS drops and low FPS in general. Is this normal?

Read full topic

item.title: Graphics Card help
item.dc:creator: @Travas Travas
item.description:
@Travas wrote:

70c is a tad bit higher than usual, I wouldn’t really worry about it though. My card runs at about 24c idling, and doesn’t go much higher while gaming.

Are you still having problems running games through your graphics card? What specific games allow you to use the dedicated graphics card, and what ones make you use the integrated graphics?

Read full topic

item.title: Graphics Card help
item.dc:creator: @SilentCJ SilentCJ
item.description:
@SilentCJ wrote:

[quote=“Tutorial, post:11, topic:508488”][quote author=Travas link=topic=626727.msg4262351#msg4262351 date=1363577568]
Looks like your fan is on min, try turning it up higher.
[/quote]
I’ve been reading about some temperatures for GPUs, and it seems my temperature is completely fine. It obviously isn’t the best, but many articles online have stated that graphic cards should be fine as long as they don’t run hotter than 70 degrees Celsius, which mine is staying around 60 whilst gaming.

Also, not only does turning the fan speed up make it annoyingly noisy, but I’ve read that it can decrease the life expectancy of it. Do you think running it at around 50% would hurt too much?[/quote]
I dunno… that is a little hot, right now mine is running at 24°C, and if I actually use the fans while gaming I can keep it at a steady 45°C… and I don’t play light games either.

What are the temperatures for the rest of the components?

And keeping the fans on won’t decrease the life expectancy, keeping it at a higher heat will.

Read full topic

item.title: Graphics Card help
item.dc:creator: @Tutorial Tutorial
item.description:
@Tutorial wrote:

Travas:

Looks like your fan is on min, try turning it up higher.

I’ve been reading about some temperatures for GPUs, and it seems my temperature is completely fine. It obviously isn’t the best, but many articles online have stated that graphic cards should be fine as long as they don’t run hotter than 70 degrees Celsius, which mine is staying around 60 whilst gaming.

Also, not only does turning the fan speed up make it annoyingly noisy, but I’ve read that it can decrease the life expectancy of it. Do you think running it at around 50% would hurt too much?

Read full topic

item.title: Graphics Card help
item.dc:creator: @Travas Travas
item.description:
@Travas wrote:

Looks like your fan is on min, try turning it up higher.

Read full topic

item.title: Graphics Card help
item.dc:creator: @Tutorial Tutorial
item.description:
@Tutorial wrote:

Travas:

You’re right, using a 3.0 card in a 2.0 or 2.1 slot won’t diminish the performance a whole lot (at least not noticeably). They are backwards compatible and work just fine in each slot. Are you sure that the settings in the control panel are fine?

I’m using all the settings that pull towards the performance side:

Also, I think I may have found another problem:

1b4fc6fd88f795d75a85f07ce1e99d94.png?1363576402783×515

I don’t really know too much about computer hardware, but I’m pretty sure the card shouldn’t be idling at 52 degrees Celsius.

Read full topic

item.title: Graphics Card help
item.dc:creator: @Travas Travas
item.description:
@Travas wrote:

You’re right, using a 3.0 card in a 2.0 or 2.1 slot won’t diminish the performance a whole lot (at least not noticeably). They are backwards compatible and work just fine in each slot. Are you sure that the settings in the control panel are fine?

Read full topic

item.title: Graphics Card help
item.dc:creator: @Tutorial Tutorial
item.description:
@Tutorial wrote:

[quote=“HcoJustin, post:6, topic:508488”]Nvidia has a problem when it decides when to use the dedicated card and when to use integrated. The majority of the time the problem comes from Java. If you look on the RS forums there is a huge thread dedicated to troubleshooting it. (Problem first came about with the laptops that have “hybrid graphics”)

The easiest way is to just disabled the integrated gpu through the bios.[/quote]
The weird thing is that it doesn’t even show my integrated graphics card under the display drivers in device manager.

Also, I should have mentioned this earlier, but I have a PCI-E 2.0 slot, whilst the card is mainly 3.0. From what I’ve been told, it shouldn’t affect the performance too much, especially to the point of me lagging on a game like RuneScape.

Read full topic

item.title: Graphics Card help
item.dc:creator: @HcoJustin HcoJustin
item.description:
@HcoJustin wrote:

Nvidia has a problem when it decides when to use the dedicated card and when to use integrated. The majority of the time the problem comes from Java. If you look on the RS forums there is a huge thread dedicated to troubleshooting it. (Problem first came about with the laptops that have “hybrid graphics”)

The easiest way is to just disabled the integrated gpu through the bios.

Read full topic

item.title: Graphics Card help
item.dc:creator: @Travas Travas
item.description:
@Travas wrote:

As CJ said there should be a control panel for modern Nvidia graphics cards with options where you can switch which card to use. From my research quite a few people have had the same type of problem with Nvidia graphics, quite weird. There are another few possibilities that could be causing the problem, but I would still suggest uninstalling your integrated graphics drivers and disabling integrated graphics in your BIOS, and then checking the Nvidia CP with the latest drivers and make sure it’s using primarily the dedicated card.

Read full topic

item.title: Graphics Card help
item.dc:creator: @Tutorial Tutorial
item.description:
@Tutorial wrote:

[quote=“SilentCJ, post:3, topic:508488”]Installed latest drivers?
Can’t say I’ve had a problem like that with my GTX 680, however I did have a friend with a Nvidia card in a laptop that used this Nvidia optimus software to reduce power usage, and it would only turn on the dedicated card when it deemed it necessary, check you haven’t got any of that kind of software.[/quote]
I installed the latest drivers today. I’m aware that this card should be able to play most games on the highest settings while holding 60+ FPS, but I can barely play RS and hold 30 FPS with on the highest settings on 1920 x 1080 resolution.

Read full topic

item.title: Graphics Card help
item.dc:creator: @SilentCJ SilentCJ
item.description:
@SilentCJ wrote:

Installed latest drivers?
Can’t say I’ve had a problem like that with my GTX 680, however I did have a friend with a Nvidia card in a laptop that used this Nvidia optimus software to reduce power usage, and it would only turn on the dedicated card when it deemed it necessary, check you haven’t got any of that kind of software.

Read full topic

item.title: Graphics Card help
item.dc:creator: @Travas Travas
item.description:
@Travas wrote:

You could try going into BIOS and disabling your integrated graphics altogether, so everything is forced to run on your new graphics card.

Read full topic
